title: Johnstown Flood National Memorial: Edward Jay Allen
body: Explore This Park    Learn About the Park     History & Culture     People     Edward Jay Allen                Edward Jay Allen (1830-1915)       Edward Jay Allen was born Edward John Allen in New York City, but raised in Pittsburgh. He attended and graduated from Duquesne University.  At 22, he went West, along the Oregon Trail to Olympia. He also served as a delegate to the Monticello Convention, that urged the split between Washington and Oregon territories. In 1853, he served as one of four scouts sent over the Naches Pass to determine if it was suitable for a wagon road. During the winter of 1853-1854, he shared a cabin with George B. McClellan and served as his private secretary. During 1854, he worked to improve the Naches Pass. In August of that same year, he led a party that successfully climed Mt. Adams. He returned to Pittsburgh in 1855 and on July 16, 1857, married Elizabeth Robinson. He served as a railroad contractor in Virginia and was in that role when the Civil War broke out. He served on the staff of General Fremont and participated in the Shenandoah Valley Campaigns in the spring of 1862. In the summer of 1862, he recruited the 155th Pennsylvania Regiment infantry and because of his work was appointed Colonel. At the Battle of Fredericksburg, the 155th led a bayonet charge against Robert E. Lee's forces on Marye's Heights. After the Battle of Gettysburg, he was medically discharged. In 1866 he became the secretary/treasurer of the Pacific & Atlantic Telegraph Company. Later in life, he became involved with the efforts to memorialize the Oregon Trail. He also published a book of poems, as he loved poetry. Edward Jay Allen died on December 26, 1915.
